docs.abstract: The economy is sending mixed signals on wages. Figuring out what’s really happening is complicated by data that’s volatile, and may be getting worse.
docs.snippet: The economy is sending mixed signals on wages. Figuring out what’s really happening is complicated by data that’s volatile, and may be getting worse.
docs.lead_paragraph: When the Labor Department reported last month that average hourly earnings had jumped 2.9 percent in January, it looked as though the long, steady recovery in the American job market might at last be translating into faster wage gains for the nation’s workers.

headline.main: Are Wage Gains Picking Up? Stalling? Questionable Data Makes It Hard to Say
headline.print_headline: Are Wage Gains Speeding Up or Stalling? Both, Apparently

docs.abstract: A survey shows strong support for President Trump’s tariff moves among his backers, but not so much among those whose votes could be in play.
docs.snippet: A survey shows strong support for President Trump’s tariff moves among his backers, but not so much among those whose votes could be in play.
docs.lead_paragraph: President Trump’s trade policies enjoy the strong backing of his supporters but are less popular among independents, moderate Republicans and others whose votes could decide control of Congress in the midterm election this fall. That could complicate Republicans’ plans to make their economic record a central argument in their case for re-election.

headline.main: Divides Over Trade Scramble Midterm Election Messaging
headline.print_headline: President’s Trade Policies Hold Perils For Both Parties in Midterm Election

byline.original: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley

docs.abstract: In a survey, nearly three in four American adults said teachers’ salaries were too low. The sentiment crossed party lines, even if raises meant higher taxes.
docs.snippet: In a survey, nearly three in four American adults said teachers’ salaries were too low. The sentiment crossed party lines, even if raises meant higher taxes.
docs.lead_paragraph: After shutting down schools and shaking up politics in six states, teachers are looking to the ballot box in their campaign for better pay and increased school funding. And their demands are meeting with widespread public support.

headline.main: Teachers Find Public Support as Campaign for Higher Pay Goes to Voters
headline.print_headline: Teachers Find Support as Campaign for Higher Salaries Goes to Voters

byline.original: By Dana Goldstein and Ben Casselman

docs.abstract: Winning the contest could mean a steeper increase in local housing costs over the next decade, a study finds. Nashville is already contemplating the impact.
docs.snippet: Winning the contest could mean a steeper increase in local housing costs over the next decade, a study finds. Nashville is already contemplating the impact.
docs.lead_paragraph: When Amazon announced in January that Nashville had made the list of 20 finalists being considered for its second North American headquarters, city leaders cheered. They saw the project as the next step in Nashville’s transformation from country-music capital into a regional and even national economic force.

headline.main: What Amazon’s New Headquarters Could Mean for Rents
headline.print_headline: Saying Hello to Amazon, and Higher Rents

docs.abstract: If the tariffs stand, along with China’s retaliatory moves, they could damage industries that have relied on a global supply chain for their recovery.
docs.snippet: If the tariffs stand, along with China’s retaliatory moves, they could damage industries that have relied on a global supply chain for their recovery.
docs.lead_paragraph: In the escalating economic showdown between the United States and China, President Trump is trying to put American shoppers first. The administration did not place tariffs on necessities like shoes and clothes, and mostly spared smartphones from the 25 percent levy on Chinese goods announced this week.

headline.main: In Sparing Consumers Tariff Burden, Trump Hit Manufacturing
headline.print_headline: U.S. Risks Trapping Manufacturers in the Crossfire

byline.original: By Natalie Kitroeff and Ben Casselman

docs.abstract: Payroll expansion was far short of February’s torrid pace and weaker than economists expected, but still yielded the 90th straight month of job gains.
docs.snippet: Payroll expansion was far short of February’s torrid pace and weaker than economists expected, but still yielded the 90th straight month of job gains.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Labor Department released its official hiring and unemployment figures for March on Friday morning, providing the latest snapshot of the American economy.

headline.main: U.S. Job Growth Eased in March; Unemployment Steady at 4.1%

docs.abstract: So-called neural networks have greatly advanced artificial intelligence. But understanding how computers make their decisions can be difficult.
docs.snippet: So-called neural networks have greatly advanced artificial intelligence. But understanding how computers make their decisions can be difficult.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Machines are starting to learn tasks on their own. They are identifying faces, recognizing spoken words, reading medical scans and even carrying on their own conversations.

headline.main: Google Researchers Are Learning How Machines Learn
headline.print_headline: Google Researchers Say They’re Learning How Machines Learn

docs.abstract: As Mark Zuckerberg, the company’s chief executive, prepares to testify before Congress, the company also said it supported the proposed Honest Ads Act.
docs.snippet: As Mark Zuckerberg, the company’s chief executive, prepares to testify before Congress, the company also said it supported the proposed Honest Ads Act.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For months, Facebook’s critics — ranging from Silicon Valley executives to Washington politicians — have been urging the company to do a better job of identifying who is buying political ads and creating pages about hot-button topics on its social media sites.

headline.main: Facebook to Require Verified Identities for Future Political Ads
headline.print_headline: Buying Political Ad on Facebook?  The Anonymous Need Not Apply

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

docs.abstract: Jan Koum’s exit is the highest-profile departure from Facebook after months of controversy at the social network. A company executive said security of user data was behind Mr. Koum’s decision.
docs.snippet: Jan Koum’s exit is the highest-profile departure from Facebook after months of controversy at the social network. A company executive said security of user data was behind Mr. Koum’s decision.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Jan Koum, a founder of the messaging app WhatsApp, sold the service to Facebook in 2014, he explained how deeply he cared about the privacy of communication. Growing up in the Soviet Union during the 1980s — when surveillance was a fact of life — had made him realize the importance of being able to speak freely, he wrote.

headline.main: WhatsApp Co-Founder Leaving Facebook Amid User Data Disputes
headline.print_headline: Resignation At Facebook In Data Fight

byline.original: By Sheera Frenkel and Cade Metz

docs.abstract: At Google, Facebook and other tech companies, executives are making statements about priorities with their seating charts.
docs.snippet: At Google, Facebook and other tech companies, executives are making statements about priorities with their seating charts.
docs.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — If you want to understand the priorities of a technology company, first look at the seating chart.

headline.main: Why A.I. Researchers at Google Got Desks Next to the Boss
headline.print_headline: A Desk Near the Boss’s Heart
